Award.AwardTitle: Radiation Reaction, Orbital Evolution, and Emitted Gravitational Waveforms from Extreme-Mass-Ratio Binaries, and Wave Extraction for Numerical relativity
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports theoretical research on topics related to gravitational waves. One of these is a study of the properties of extreme mass ratio binary inspirals where a stellar mass black hole orbits a supermassive black hole, emits gravitational waves, and eventually falls in. Such a system could be an important source for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA) . Accurate calculation of the orbit of the stellar mass black hole and of the gravitational radiation produced require improved understanding of fundamental issues in Einstein's theory of general relativity such as the "self-force" on the small black hole due to the gravitational radiation it emits and how that changes the orbit. Another project is to develop a method to extract gravitational waveforms from large scale numerical simulations of (comparable mass) binary black hole systems.

Better understanding of gravitational wave sources and waveforms will maximize the discovery opportunities presented by ground-based gravitational wave detectors now operating and future space-based detectors. Undergraduate and graduate students will participate in this research. The PI plans to continue his program of public outreach and his involvement with nearby minority serving institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored a number of topics in gravitational physics:

(1) (i) Black hole physics: we studied the rate at which perturbations of rotating black holes decay at late times. We proposed a correction for the formula that describes the late-time decay rate based on numerical simulations in 2+1D. We showed that  for excitations of higher multipole moments than the initial perturbation, the decay rate is slower than previously thought. We proposed a mechanism for the coupling of the modes in orders of the quire of the spin angular momentum of the black hole, and tested it numerically. (ii) We provided an explanation for a puzzling apparent behavior of the decaying multipole field, dubbed "splitting": the late-time rates seem to depend on whether finite distance observers are in the strong field domain or far away from the rotating black hole. The far-field "splitting" is explained by competition between projected modes. The near-horizon "splitting" is due to excitation of lower multipole modes that back excite the multipole mode for which ‘splitting’ is observed. In both cases "splitting" is an intermediate effect, such that asymptotically in time strong field rates are valid at all finite distances.

(2) Wave extraction for numerical relativity: In practice most numerical relativity codes estimate the flux of gravitational waves the the flux of energy carried to distant observers at finite distances, although it is assumed that the asymptotic expressions hold. We propose that more accurate estimates can be obtained if finite distance corrections are considered in the fitting functions. We show that the leading finite distance corrections drop faster at finite distances as inverse posters of the distance then previously thought.

(3) Radiation reaction in general relativity: When a small object moves in a gravitational field, its geodesic motion is corrected by the interaction of the mass with its own field, an effect attributed to the so-called "self force." We study the orbital evolution and emitted gravitational waveforms from quasi-circular orbits around a Schwarzschild black hole for extreme and intermediate mass-ratio systems, and find, for the first time, the waveform dephasing due to (i) the first-order conservative piece of the self force, and (ii) the second-order radiative piece of the self force. We argue that the former is important for gravitational wave astronomy, but the latter is likely to be negligible, although they both contribute in the same power of the mass ratio.
 
(4) When black holes are perturbed thy emit gravitational waves in specific frequencies, that depend only on the parameters of the black holes, but not on the detail of the perturbations. Such radiation modes are known as quasi-normal modes. We estimate the signal-to-noise ratio of black hole quasi-normal mode sources. We replace the older technique of all-sky averaging with Monte Carlo simulations. We find that for a particular range of black hole masses (4-7 million solar masses, a typical mass range for black holes at the center of galaxies) the signal-to-noise ratio is significantly higher than previously thought. This effect implies higher event rate for space-bourne gravitational-wave detectors such as eLISA/NGO.

This project was conducted in an EPSCoR state, and in part at an HBCU, serving a student body of over 94% minority students, mostly African Americans. It supported two graduate students, one of which is female and the other of an ethnic minority group, and resulted in thirteen publications in peer revised journals and conference proceedings, and numerous presentations in conferences, workshops, seminars and colloquia.
